Description: Egyptian terracotta figure. Grotesque style bald head, broken away from its separately made figure, probably male and perhaps a priest, but it might be that of a woman. An incised line on the left side runs from brow to behind left ear. At the base of the neck is a short tenon for insertion into its body. Apparently hollow, from a two-piece mould. Brown Nile silt with a grey core and frequent fine gold mica and rare quartz and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Many parallels from Naukratis the (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. G 107; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, GR.40.1887; Walters 1903, C 625; Fischer 1994, no. 437; Bailey 2008: 151, pl. 106. no. 3573-3578, see more detailed GR1886,0401.1412), but also 2nd century BC examples from Smyrna in Asia Minor (Burn & Higgins 2001: pl. 71-2, no. 2396-2404). Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen: Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C625)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.510) (Phase 1)
